addressleaf.section:
To my L. T
re
r Sep
t
24 1592 by M
r
Kennet messenger

page.lettertext:
fol.323r
14 Sep
t
To my L. T
re
r from M
r
Bodly
May it please yo
r
good L. The
General states
upon
e soddaine have dissolved their assemblie,
and are gone
e greater part
by
w
t
c
o
as
sent of the
rest, to consult w
t
e
Councel
, w
ch
continueth at
Swol
, about the imploiment of their army
e rest
of this sommer. I have alwaies suspected as
I have formerly written, that they would be
very
but
slowe in geving order for
Berghen
,
at there might
be
for
other troupes
to c
o
thither
in
e places of those
at are named
for
France
. And nowe they are departed, and have
left no resolution: upon hope, as I conjecture,
at
rather then
e Gouvernor will leave
e towne
un-
w
t
fournished
or a garris
o
, and so in danger of
e Enemie, he will
not suffer
e companies to be drawen from thens.
Howbeit to prevent them in this dealing, I have signi-
fied by letter to
e
states of Zeland
, who are next
adjoining unto Berghen,
at if nether from
e States
heere, nor out of their repartition,
e forsaid supplie
be presently sent, there is charge already given to
her
Ma
ties
officer, to stay
e weekely paies of as many
companies in Berghen, as are by order of her Ma
tie
to be transported into France. This, I am as-
sured, will so quicken those of
Zeland
,
at they will
make but smalle delay in sending a supp
lement
lie
:
for
at
e souldiers till then must live upon
e c
o
trey.
To that effect I have also written to
S
r
Thomas Shirleis
officer at
Middelbourgh
, to refraine from sending
any
further
pay unto Berghen
till
e c
o
panies be demissed
And
I have like-
wise acquainted S
r
Thomas Morgan w
t
my course, w
t
special advise to use his care and discretion in pro-
ceeding w
t
e privitie of
e Captaines of
e Garrison
that no daungerous inconvenience may falle unto
the towne: w
ch
I knowe he may perfourme without
any trouble or disorder. And thus I thought it
fol.323v
expedient to meete w
t
e states in their backward
dealing w
t
her Ma
tie
. Wheras I have
bin required both by yo
r
L. and by my
L. Admirals
letters, to become an earnest suito
r
for
e enlargem
t
of certaine Englishe sea men, w
ch
were prisoners in
Enchusen
and
Amsterdam
, I made petition
therupon
it
to
e General states, and likewise to
e college of the
states of Holland
, whome
e matter most concerned
in
e name of all my
LL.
The effect of
at w
ch
I
had said
delivered,
I exhibited after, be
ing thereto required, in writing,
u
to th
e
wherof heereinclosed
I have sent yo
w
e transcript. From those
publicke assemblies I had never no other answear,
then they are wont to give commonly to a motion of
importance, That they would take some time to con
sult upon it. But by certaine in particular,
whom
I earnestly solicited
, I was alwaies put in hope,
That wheras
e prisoners wer all condemned to
die, and to be presently executed, they had staied
their proceeding upon this intercession, and
as they
were persuaded
, would onely execut their sentence
upon
e principal offendo
rs
, and graunt a pardon
to
e multitude. I did also request
M
r
Caro
[ns]
assistance, who dealt in
e suite very carefully and
frindly, and was alwaies intertened w
t
e like
kinde of hope. Howbeit contrary to both
o
r
expectations, they have onely spared suche you
[ng men]
as were under
e age of 18 yeres, and two
[or three]
more, upon importunat request, and have pu
[t to]
execution about
e number of 40. What
[rea-]
sons I alleaged, to cause them to extend a f
[urther]
favo
r
to
e rest, because they are sette downe
[in]
writing heerew
t
, I knowe a double rehersall
would be tedious to yo
r
L. Many of this
[contrey]
doe mervail at their rigo
r
, lamenting both th
[e losse]
fol.324r
of so great a number, and of so many proper persons,
as in a maner they were all, and of mariners at
lest a dousen, sufficiently skilled to take any charge.
Whether it were not somwhat needefull,
at ether by her
Ma
tie
, or by my LL. of
e Councel, they should by some
letter be touched to
e quicke, for their rigorous pro-
ceeding, and their slender regard, aswell unto the
reason as to
e instance of the
ir
suite, I leave it so
proposed
to yo
r
L.
to consider
: humbly beseeching yow
to acquaint my L. Admiral w
t
as muche as hath
bin done: who recommended
e saving of two above
the rest, of w
ch
e one named
Webbe
hath obtened his
pardon,
and
but
e other was deceased in prison before.
The wether heere hath b
i
so strang, and
e winde so c
o
trary to
e c
o
ming downe of
e
c
o
panies,
at they were not yesternight arri-
ved at
Dort
. Otherwise fr
o
e time
at they
were shipped, they might have bin at
Flushing
.
But yo
r
L. may account,
at
e very next
wind, if it hold any time, will carie
them into
Normandy.
Once for my self it
is [.] not possible for me to doe more th
e
I
did to hasten them a way.
